title: H2O: the FT investigation's big finale
text:
One scoop to start: Bankrupt crypto lender BlockFi is suing Sam Bankman-Fried over shares in Robinhood that the FTX founder allegedly pledged as collateral earlier this month.

And another thing to start: A woman who says she was raped at convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein's New York home by Leon Black, the co-founder of US investment group Apollo Global Management, has sued the former executive and Epstein's estate in a Manhattan court. A lawyer for Black, Susan Estrich, said the latest allegations against her client “are categorically false and part of a scheme to . . . destroy his reputation”.

In today's newsletter:

  • H2O: bye-bye Bruno?

  • The activist fight that has Wall Street's attention

  • Paris Saint-Germain seeks market's approval

Crastes finds himself under the financial guillotine 

Back when he was still riding high, Bruno Crastes was happy to hit out at regulation.

When the tanned and silver-haired chief executive of H2O Asset Management picked up an award for his market-beating returns in 2018, the Frenchman used his acceptance speech to assert that his industry had become “corrupted by all this regulation and all this risk management”.

Now, four years later, Crastes is facing the prospect of being banned from the investment industry by his home country's financial regulator for a decade.

On Friday, France's Autorité des Marchés Financiers recommended a record €75mn fine for H2O, alongside a €15mn fine on Crastes and a €3mn penalty for the firm's chief investment officer, Vincent Chailley. It's also seeking to ban Crastes from managing funds or an investment firm for a decade.

What prompted the downfall of Crastes and H2O, which at its peak managed more than €30bn and was widely feted as one of the top- performing asset managers in Europe?

It all started when the FT decided to carry out a little due diligence.

Back in 2019, DD's Rob Smith and Cynthia O'Murchu from the FT's investigations desk pored over H2O's fund filings and made a startling discovery: the firm had well over €1bn invested in illiquid bonds linked to Lars Windhorst, a German financier with a chequered past that included a criminal conviction.

The reaction was immediate: investors yanked €8bn from H2O's funds, while billions of euros were wiped off the market value of French bank Natixis, which first seeded the firm back in 2010.

Yet, while H2O withstood the initial fallout — during which Crastes even publicly praised Windhorst as “extremely talented” — the French regulator on Friday laid bare a series of “grave” rule breaches at the firm. An official from the AMF argued at a public hearing in Paris that H2O wasn't even authorised to hold such illiquid bonds in retail funds in the first place.

Despite continued revelations in the FT in the three years since its initial exposé, H2O still managed north of €12bn at the last count. Those loyal clients now face a decision.

On Monday, H2O sought to reassure them that the regulator hadn't accused it of committing fraud, describing the alleged infractions as concerning “essentially technical matters” in a letter to clients. We'll discover just how technical the matter was when the AMF finalises its penalties in the coming weeks.

Whatever the outcome, the episode is another reminder of the importance of this newsletter's namesake: due diligence.

During Friday's hearing, Crastes said that H2O didn't uncover any information about Windhorst's criminal conviction in research it carried out before first investing in bonds linked to the financier.

DD would recommend that all of our readers incorporate a simple Google search into their due diligence process to avoid similar mishaps.

The ‘Trojan horse' debate captivating Wall Street

The high-finance version of “never get into a land war in Asia” might be “do not start a proxy fight in Orange County”, a top investment banker recently told DD.

The posh OC has had its share of corporate battles over the years: Bill Ackman's 2015 brawl with Botox maker Allergan; a 2013 boardroom scrap between Emulux and Elliott Management; and Broadcom's 2018 fight for Qualcomm.

The latest Southern California brawl involves Masimo, a medical device maker with an $8bn enterprise value. Its antagonist, Politan Capital Management, a new hedge fund launched by veteran activist Quentin Koffey of Elliott and DE Shaw fame, is seeking a seat on its board.

The fight has yet to even reach the proxy stage. Rather, as DD's Sujeet Indap writes, Masimo is challenging Politan to reveal details about itself — including who exactly its financial backers are.

Koffey could be a “Trojan horse” representing “sovereign entities that do not respect — and have attempted to steal — intellectual property belonging to US companies”, Masimo has speculated in legal filings.

These so-called “advance notice” provisions in corporate bylaws are being litigated in Delaware: companies say they should have the right to ask for detailed information about potential dissident investors. Activists say these rules simply stifle shareholder democracy.

The fight has captivated the elite lawyers and bankers who advise on proxy fights. Semafor reported that the boardroom stalwart Wachtell Lipton decided against working with Masimo because it found the bylaw provisions to be too extreme for its tastes. Another top corporate defender, Sidley Austin, raised eyebrows by publishing a public memo speculating that Masimo had flown too close to the sun.

Masimo is working with Paul Hastings, which recruited star M&A lawyer Eduardo Gallardo from Gibson Dunn earlier this year along with litigators at Quinn Emanuel.

The Masimo/Koffey quarrel comes during a particularly heated moment in corporate activism: a new so-called “universal proxy card” rolled out by the US Securities and Exchange Commission has made it easier than ever for shareholders to run against company-backed directors.

Masimo isn't the only company hopping on the defence. While these kinds of disputes often settle before court rulings, all eyes will be on the fight as investors and lawyers wonder whether corporate America has finally taken it too far.

PSG plays for Premier League-level cash

France is the undisputed minnow of Europe's “big five” football leagues, but Paris Saint-Germain isn't letting that get in the way of a chunky target valuation.

The French champions are in talks to sell up to 15 per cent of the club at a valuation of more than €4bn, PSG president Nasser al-Khelaifi told the FT. That would be a big boost for Qatar Sports Investments, which bought PSG for about €70mn back in 2011.

Chelsea FC, you'll recall, went for £2.5bn this year in a takeover led by US billionaire Todd Boehly. And that's a club in the English Premier League, Europe's richest by some way.

A €4bn valuation would put PSG on seven times trailing revenues of €556mn, even more than Chelsea received, as Lex notes. That'd be a nice chunk of change considering dealmaking has slowed just about everywhere else.

Paying around €400mn or so for a tenth or so of a business is of course a far different proposition to shelling out for a full takeover. PSG's fortunes will be closely watched by Manchester United and Liverpool: England's two-best known clubs are also considering their options.

But there's another reason why investors might be willing to bet on PSG. In the landscape of European football, al-Khelaifi has a better vantage point than most.

He runs one of the region's top clubs and knows the French league, chairs the influential European Club Association and broadcaster beIN Sports, and sits on the executive committee of European football's governing body Uefa.

The former professional tennis player, a crucial force in repelling the breakaway European Super League last year, has been central to building PSG into an attractive home for star players. Before the Qataris showed up, PSG hadn't won the domestic league title since 1994. These days Lionel Messi, Neymar and Kylian Mbappé play up front.

Even so, investors must weigh up whether PSG can defy its role as a big fish in a small pond — or decide that France's Ligue 1 has seen the bottom after a tough pandemic.

Job moves

  • Marlboro cigarette maker Philip Morris International has made a number of changes to its senior management ahead of a potential takeover of smokeless tobacco group Swedish Match.

  • French satellite operator Eutelsat has appointed Christophe Caudrelier, previously an operating partner at Tikehau Ace Capital Partners, as chief financial officer. He replaces Sandrine Téran, who announced that she was stepping down in September.

  • Revolution Beauty has appointed City veteran Bob Holt to replace co-founder Adam Minto as chief executive, who departed the role in September when auditors highlighted “serious concerns” about the group's accounts.

  • EY has hired FTI's former head of corporate governance and activism Rodolfo Araujo to lead the auditing and consulting firm's environmental, social and governance efforts, per Reuters.

  • Denis Sverdlov, the billionaire founder of UK electric vehicle start-up Arrival, is stepping down as CEO and will be replaced by former Marvel Entertainment boss Peter Cuneo. President and strategy chief Avinash Rugoobur is additionally stepping down “for personal reasons” but will remain on the board.

  • Baby products retailer Mothercare has appointed Daniel Le Vesconte, who will join in the new year from fashion brand Abercrombie & Fitch, as CEO following profit hits due to the halting of its Russian operations.

Smart reads

Blackstone plays defence The private equity group's Real Estate Income Trust has become a quiet concern to some investors and analysts. Our FT Alphaville colleagues break down its latest results.

The mayor of Tinseltown Hollywood is an “old money town” run by half a dozen people, as media executives tell the FT, and returning Disney boss Bob Iger is one of them. Dealmaking could be an essential part of his second act.

And one smart watch: The sudden departure of Carlyle boss Kewsong Lee shocked Wall Street. DD's Antoine Gara digs into the curious case of his resignation.
